itemDescription: Irish nationalist journalist, barrister, parliamentarian and mercenary

wikipedia_page.main: Charles James Patrick Mahon (17 March 1800 – 15 June 1891), known as the O'Gorman Mahon or James Patrick Mahon, was an Irish nationalist journalist, barrister, parliamentarian and international mercenary.

response: *James Patrick Mahon, known as the O'Gorman Mahon, journalist, barrister, parliamentarian
*15 June – James Patrick Mahon, Irish nationalist politician and international mercenary (born 1800).

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1886 United Kingdom general election
response: *June 1887: County Carlow – James Patrick Mahon (Irish Liberal) replacing John Aloysius Blake (Irish Parliamentary Party) who died 22 May 1887
*James Patrick Mahon was 79 when he held the 1879 Clare by-election and 87 when he held the 1887 County Carlow by-election for the Irish Nationalists.
*17 March – James Patrick Mahon, Irish nationalist politician and international mercenary (died 1891).
The first Roman Catholic general election victors in the UK Parliament were at the 1830 general election. They included Daniel O'Connell and James Patrick Mahon in Clare.
* James Patrick Mahon – Irish nationalist politician and mercenary

link_mentions.page: Records of members of parliament of the United Kingdom
response: :James Patrick Mahon: Clare 8; Ennis 1; County Carlow 10
The first Roman Catholic general election victors in the UK Parliament were at the 1830 general election. They included Daniel O'Connell and James Patrick Mahon in Clare.

response: | John Dillon, Charles Stewart Parnell, James Lysaght Finegan, John Barry, Joseph Biggar, Garrett Byrne, William Corbet, John Daly, Mr. Dawson, Thomas Patrick Gill, Edmund Dwyer Gray, Timothy Michael Healy, Richard Lalor, Edmund Leamy, James Leahy, Justin McCarthy, James Carlile McCoan, Edward Marum, Robert Henry Metge, Isaac Nelson, Arthur O'Connor, Thomas Power O'Connor, Daniel O'Donoghue, James Patrick Mahon, William Henry O'Sullivan, John O'Connor Power, John Redmond, Thomas Sexton, Alexander Martin Sullivan, Timothy Daniel Sullivan, Bernard Charles Molloy, James Joseph O'Kelly, Frank Hugh O'Donnell, Richard Power, Richard O'Shaughnessy
*James Patrick Mahon (1800–1891), Irish nationalist journalist, barrister, parliamentarian and international mercenary
